title: Thoughts on Go after writing 3 websites
Summary
b
: in my experience Go is a good language for building websites/web servers.

inline_content.Text: : in my experience Go is a good language for building websites/web servers.

title: It’s easy to get excited about new technology like Go. The question is: how does it stand up to scrutiny after daily use?

inline_content.Text: It’s easy to get excited about new technology like Go. The question is: how does it stand up to scrutiny after daily use?

title: I’ve written 4 web applications in Go, they’ve been running in production for several months so I feel justified in publishing my opinion.

inline_content.Text: I’ve written 4 web applications in Go, they’ve been running in production for several months so I feel justified in publishing my opinion.

title: In the past I wrote web applications in Perl, PHP, Python (web.py, Tornado, App Engine) so those are the technologies I campare Go to.

inline_content.Text: In the past I wrote web applications in Perl, PHP, Python (web.py, Tornado, App Engine) so those are the technologies I campare Go to.

title: Of the 4 websites,
AppTranslator
a
http://www.apptranslator.org/
is a web service for crowd-sourcing translations for software. It was written completely from scratch.

inline_content.Text: is a web service for crowd-sourcing translations for software. It was written completely from scratch.

title: QuickNotes
a
https://github.com/kjk/quicknotes
is a note-taking application. Also written from scratch.

inline_content.Text: is a note-taking application. Also written from scratch.

title: Fofou
a
http://forums.fofou.org/
is a simple forum. It is a port of an earlier version I did in Python for App Engine. Finally,
this web site
a
//blog.kowalczyk.info
is a blog engine (also a port of an earlier App Engine version in Python).

inline_content.Text: is a simple forum. It is a port of an earlier version I did in Python for App Engine. Finally,
is a blog engine (also a port of an earlier App Engine version in Python).

title: One reason to migrate from App Engine to my own server was to save money. At my levels of traffic (~3 requests per second) I was paying ~$80/month, mostly for frontend instance hours.

inline_content.Text: One reason to migrate from App Engine to my own server was to save money. At my levels of traffic (~3 requests per second) I was paying ~$80/month, mostly for frontend instance hours.

title: Another reason was to do more complex processing. App Engine is great but being a fully managed service, it limits what you can do.

inline_content.Text: Another reason was to do more complex processing. App Engine is great but being a fully managed service, it limits what you can do.

title: Finally, I wanted to see how Go will handle a real project.

inline_content.Text: Finally, I wanted to see how Go will handle a real project.

title: I used to run them all on a single $60/month
Kimsufi 24
a
https://www.kimsufi.co.uk/
dedicated server but now I’m deploying to
CoreOS running on $5/month Digital Ocean
a
/article/5/Blueprint-for-deploying-web-apps-on-CoreOS.html

inline_content.Text: I used to run them all on a single $60/month
dedicated server but now I’m deploying to

title: Things you need for building a web application

inline_content.Text: Things you need for building a web application

title: What functionality is typically needed for writing a web application and how does Go support it?

inline_content.Text: What functionality is typically needed for writing a web application and how does Go support it?

title: A very capable http server is part of standard library in package (
net/http
a
https://golang.org/pkg/net/http/

inline_content.Text: A very capable http server is part of standard library in package (

title: It parses incoming http requests and provides a way to send http responses back.

inline_content.Text: It parses incoming http requests and provides a way to send http responses back.

title: It supports http/2 out of the box.

inline_content.Text: It supports http/2 out of the box.

title: High-level web frameworks provide url routing i.e. a way to say “call this function to handle this url”. Go has a built-in simple router. I also use
mux
a
http://www.gorillatoolkit.org/pkg/mux
, which is built on top of the built-in router.

inline_content.Text: High-level web frameworks provide url routing i.e. a way to say “call this function to handle this url”. Go has a built-in simple router. I also use
, which is built on top of the built-in router.

title: A lot of what web server does is returning html which is greatly simplified by using templates. Go has a powerful
html/template
a
https://golang.org/pkg/html/template/
library for that. It’s roughly equivalent of Django or Tornado templates from Python world.

inline_content.Text: A lot of what web server does is returning html which is greatly simplified by using templates. Go has a powerful
library for that. It’s roughly equivalent of Django or Tornado templates from Python world.

title: There are other templating libraries for Go but I found html/template good enough for my needs so I didn’t try the alternatives.

inline_content.Text: There are other templating libraries for Go but I found html/template good enough for my needs so I didn’t try the alternatives.

title: To generate cookies that cannot be spoofed or hi-jacked, I used
securecookie
a
http://www.gorillatoolkit.org/pkg/securecookie
library

inline_content.Text: To generate cookies that cannot be spoofed or hi-jacked, I used

database/sql

https://golang.org/pkg/database/sql/
package in standard library and mature drivers for all popular databases (

a
https://github.com/lib/pq
MySQl
a

and
many others

title: There are three oauth libraries that I know of. I used
garyburd/go-oauth
a
https://github.com/garyburd/go-oauth
and
golang/oauth
a
https://github.com/golang/oauth2
. They both work and I implemented login via Twitter, GitHub and Google.

inline_content.Text: There are three oauth libraries that I know of. I used
. They both work and I implemented login via Twitter, GitHub and Google.

title: One cannot respect a blog engine that doesn’t provide full-text rss feed. I couldn’t find an existing package so I build a simple (and small) library for
generating atom feeds
a
https://github.com/kjk/atomgenerator

JSON
a
http://golang.org/pkg/encoding/json/
and
XML
a
http://golang.org/pkg/encoding/xml/

inline_content.Text: Go has a built-in support for

title: Modern web application are often implemented as JSON API server on the backend and Single Page Application on the front-end that generates HTML based on JSON returned from the server.

inline_content.Text: Modern web application are often implemented as JSON API server on the backend and Single Page Application on the front-end that generates HTML based on JSON returned from the server.

title: Returning JSON responses based on data from Go structs is very easy.

inline_content.Text: Returning JSON responses based on data from Go structs is very easy.

title: S3 access, support for zip files

inline_content.Text: S3 access, support for zip files

title: This one is not universally needed. My web apps do backups by uploading data to s3, often as .zip archives.

inline_content.Text: This one is not universally needed. My web apps do backups by uploading data to s3, often as .zip archives.

title: Go has support for creating and decompressing zip and tar archives in the standard library. For s3 support I use
official AWS SDK
a
https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go

inline_content.Text: Go has support for creating and decompressing zip and tar archives in the standard library. For s3 support I use

title: This is not specific to writing web server - all your important code should have unit tests.

inline_content.Text: This is not specific to writing web server - all your important code should have unit tests.

title: Deploying a new version of your code to the server is a pain in the ass regardless of the language used but Go makes it relatively easy.

inline_content.Text: Deploying a new version of your code to the server is a pain in the ass regardless of the language used but Go makes it relatively easy.

title: I test my code locally on Mac but deploy to Linux-based server.

inline_content.Text: I test my code locally on Mac but deploy to Linux-based server.

title: Thanks to Go’s support for cross-compilation I can build a linux binary on mac.

inline_content.Text: Thanks to Go’s support for cross-compilation I can build a linux binary on mac.

title: In the past I would copy the binary and other necesssary files to Linux server using Fabric or Ansible scripts.

inline_content.Text: In the past I would copy the binary and other necesssary files to Linux server using Fabric or Ansible scripts.

title: Those days I pacakge them as Docker containers and
deploy that using simple shell scripts
a
/article/5/Blueprint-for-deploying-web-apps-on-CoreOS.html

inline_content.Text: Those days I pacakge them as Docker containers and
deploy that using simple shell scripts

title: I find it crucial for productivity to quickly deploy new versions. THat’s why I write deploy scripts early in the process.

inline_content.Text: I find it crucial for productivity to quickly deploy new versions. THat’s why I write deploy scripts early in the process.

title: In the past I would run multiple services on a single Linux server, using nginx to multiplex.

inline_content.Text: In the past I would run multiple services on a single Linux server, using nginx to multiplex.

title: Those days for simplicity I use a single server for each program. That makes setup and deployment easier (no need for nginx anymore).

inline_content.Text: Those days for simplicity I use a single server for each program. That makes setup and deployment easier (no need for nginx anymore).

title: The source for all three projects is publicly available on Github, using liberal BSD license:
App Translator
a
https://github.com/kjk/apptranslator
Fofou
a
https://github.com/kjk/fofou
blog
a
https://github.com/kjk/blog

inline_content.Text: The source for all three projects is publicly available on Github, using liberal BSD license:

title: Feel free to learn from the code or use it in your own projects.

inline_content.Text: Feel free to learn from the code or use it in your own projects.

title: I think writing non-trivial web services is a sweet spot for Go.

inline_content.Text: I think writing non-trivial web services is a sweet spot for Go.

title: Most of the needed functionality is part of standard library and 3rdp party libraries are plantiful for more esoteric functionality.

inline_content.Text: Most of the needed functionality is part of standard library and 3rdp party libraries are plantiful for more esoteric functionality.

title: Writing in Go is almost as fast and fluent as writing in Python but the code is order of magnitude faster and uses less memory.

inline_content.Text: Writing in Go is almost as fast and fluent as writing in Python but the code is order of magnitude faster and uses less memory.
